issue.title: Array: Clarify `remove` semantics?
issue.body:
(Sorry to generate so many issues (of varying legitimacy) lately, been putting the language through some paces!) 

It's quite possible I'm just misunderstanding how binding works, so this may be a non-issue, please let me know!

Currently, `Array.remove` removes elements from an array 'in-place' and returns the resulting array. While there's nothing wrong with this behavior, it does result in some scenarios in which the semantics are a bit muddled. Consider the following example:

```clojure
(def my-array (the (Array Int) (zero)) ;; initialize an array and bind it to my-array

(defn print-and-remove [] 
  (foreach [item my-array] 
    (do (IO.print item)
           (remove item @&my-array))))
```

At a glance, this seems to make intuitive sense: for each item in the array, print it, then remove it from the array, in place. I'd expect both functions in this case to be effectful types returning `()`. It is odd that we need to copy the bound array to manipulate it in place (on this point, I might be doing something wrong). 

If you try to define this, you'll get an error: 

```
I canâ€™t match the types `(Array r17)` and `()` within `(do (let [item  ...  1)))`.

  (let [item (Array.nth xs i)] (do (IO.print item) (Array.remove item (copy (ref my-array))))) : (Array r17)
  At line 132, column 15 in '/Users/scottolsen/dev/Carp/core/Macros.carp'

  Statement in do-expression : ()
  At line 131, column 9 in '/Users/scottolsen/dev/Carp/core/Macros.carp'
```

This is only problematic when iterating over the array with foreach--if we change the types to match, this works fine:

```clojure
(defn print-and-remove [] 
  (foreach [item my-array] 
    (do (IO.print item)
           (set! my-array (remove item @&my-array)))))
```

But `remove` removes elements in place... so it's redundant to call `set!` on `my-array`!
...but also it's not, since we copied it to use it! (because that value was already owned by the binding). However, the initial reading of this code would suggest a redundancy and seems to conflict with my understanding of the term 'in-place'--I'd expect to not have to reset the value of a binding if the function operated on its value 'in-place'. But maybe this is a doc or personal issue? Maybe in-place is not the correct terminology here, or maybe I don't understand it properly?

Since the majority of effectful operations in Carp return `()` I would expect an in-place operation to be treated as effectful, remove the elements from a referenced array and return `()`, while a `copy-filter` based implementation (`copy-remove`?) can return the resulting array.

That said, it looks as though `endo-filter` also returns the resulting array and takes ownership. I'll admit that I'm not entirely sure what taking ownership means when the value is bound to a variable as in the case above--is the variable unbound or reset upon the function's taking ownership--then it makes sense that we'd have to set again--but if we're copying anyway...does it make sense? Perhaps I'm wrongheaded on this one, but thought I'd bring it up in case it's a potential point of confusion for others too! This may just be one that warrants a quick remediation of my understanding and notions, then we can move merrily on. ðŸ˜…

comment.body:
I understand that this is confusing, the documentation string should probably clarify "in place" a bit more â€“ or use some other terminology there. What it means in this case is that the function `remove` won't copy the array internally but instead modify it and return the same instance. But yes, "in place" is used to describe the `!` family of functions to, that are effectful and return `()`. Do you have an idea for how to make the docs clearer in this regard?

I don't think the name `copy-remove` is good since it doesn't copy. We could have a `remove!` function though, that would help you write the code you want to write above. The problem with mixing owning functions and loops (like `foreach`) is that the memory analyser doesn't know what will happen inside the owning function so it can't just give away the same piece of memory in each iteration (the owning function might just eat it). So you often get cleaner code if you use a more functional approach, like `map` / `filter` / `reduce` when using the owning functions. 

Perhaps try that, and if you're not happy with the result we can add a `remove!` function?  Please let us know how it goes and let's discuss this further here, it's really great to hear about the actual experience of using the language since that gives us information on what ideas work and what needs to be adjusted!

forkee.name: hello-rust
forkee.description: A simple hello world in Rust, with a Nix environment

issue.title: Array: Clarify `remove` semantics?
issue.body:
(Sorry to generate so many issues (of varying legitimacy) lately, been putting the language through some paces!) 

It's quite possible I'm just misunderstanding how binding works, so this may be a non-issue, please let me know!

Currently, `Array.remove` removes elements from an array 'in-place' and returns the resulting array. While there's nothing wrong with this behavior, it does result in some scenarios in which the semantics are a bit muddled. Consider the following example:

```clojure
(def my-array (the (Array Int) (zero)) ;; initialize an array and bind it to my-array

    (do (IO.print item)

```

I'd expect both functions in this case to be effectful types returning `()`. It is odd that we need to copy the bound array to manipulate it in place (on this point, I might be doing something wrong). 

If you try to define this, you'll get an error:

  (let [item (Array.nth xs i)] (do (IO.print item) (Array.remove item (copy (ref my-array))))) : (Array r17)
  At line 132, column 15 in '/Users/scottolsen/dev/Carp/core/Macros.carp'

  Statement in do-expression : ()
  At line 131, column 9 in '/Users/scottolsen/dev/Carp/core/Macros.carp'
```

```clojure

But maybe this is a doc or personal issue? Maybe in-place is not the correct terminology here, or maybe I don't understand it properly?

Since the majority of effectful operations in Carp return `()` I would expect an in-place operation to be treated as effectful, remove the elements from a referenced array and return `()`, while a `copy-filter` based implementation (`copy-remove`?) can return the resulting array.

Perhaps I'm wrongheaded on this one, but thought I'd bring it up in case it's a potential point of confusion for others too! issue.title: Non-exhaustive patterns in Concretize

milestone.title: Version 0.3.0
milestone.description: So, it's definitely about time to release an official version of Carp. We need to discuss exactly what goes in it, but it should provide a nice and usable experience. Polishing what we have is more important than tons of new features.

issue.body:
When I attempt to use the following definitions, I get an error about non-exhaustive patterns in `concretize.hs`

```clojure
(def scheduled-propagators (the (Array (Fn [] ())) (zero)))                 
    ;; all propagators ever scheduled during the scheduler's lifetime.          
(def history (the (Array (Fn [] ())) (zero)))  

(defn run-alerted []                                                        
        (do                                                                     
          (clear-schedule)                                                      
          (foreach [propagator &scheduled-propagators]                          
            (~propagator))                                                      
          (if (propagators-scheduled?)                                          
              (run-alerted)                                                     
              (State.Done))))    
```

My guess is that concretize doesn't yet account for the `()` type? either that or there's something wrong in my carp code. 

Happy to look into this!

comment.body: We should definitely check type definitions more thoroughly before handing them off. I can do that on the weekend maybe.

issue.title: Entering `help` into the repl crashes it

milestone.title: Version 0.3.0
milestone.description: So, it's definitely about time to release an official version of Carp. We need to discuss exactly what goes in it, but it should provide a nice and usable experience. Polishing what we have is more important than tons of new features.

comment.body: No, I fixed the crash but there isn't a helpful message anymore.

issue.title: Make it easier to use functions as type members in the repl?

milestone.title: Version 0.3.0
milestone.description: So, it's definitely about time to release an official version of Carp. We need to discuss exactly what goes in it, but it should provide a nice and usable experience. Polishing what we have is more important than tons of new features.

issue.body:
Currently, it seems that the repl has trouble when dealing with anonymous function as a type members unless the result is bound:

```clojure
(deftype EG (Foo [String (Fn [] ())]) (Bar []))
(EG.Foo @"foo" (fn [] ()))
./out/main.c:368:17: error: expected ')'
void _Lambda_(EG.Foo (String.copy "Foo") (fn _LT__GT_ [] ()))_7();
                ^
./out/main.c:368:14: note: to match this '('
void _Lambda_(EG.Foo (String.copy "Foo") (fn _LT__GT_ [] ()))_7();
             ^
./out/main.c:368:62: error: expected function body after function declarator
void _Lambda_(EG.Foo (String.copy "Foo") (fn _LT__GT_ [] ()))_7();
                                                             ^
./out/main.c:371:17: error: expected ')'
void _Lambda_(EG.Foo (copy "Foo") (fn _LT__GT_ [] ()))_7();
                ^
./out/main.c:371:14: note: to match this '('
void _Lambda_(EG.Foo (copy "Foo") (fn _LT__GT_ [] ()))_7();
             ^
./out/main.c:371:55: error: expected function body after function declarator
void _Lambda_(EG.Foo (copy "Foo") (fn _LT__GT_ [] ()))_7();
                                                      ^
./out/main.c:1659:24: warning: implicit declaration of function 'Function_copy__void_Fn___void' is invalid in C99 [-Wimplicit-function-declaration]
    copy.Foo.member1 = Function_copy__void_Fn___void(&(pRef->Foo.member1));
                       ^
./out/main.c:1659:22: error: assigning to 'Lambda' from incompatible type 'int'
    copy.Foo.member1 = Function_copy__void_Fn___void(&(pRef->Foo.member1));
                     ^ ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
./out/main.c:1692:10: warning: implicit declaration of function 'Function_prn__void' is invalid in C99 [-Wimplicit-function-declaration]
  temp = Function_prn__void(&p->Foo.member1); 
         ^
./out/main.c:1692:8: warning: incompatible integer to pointer conversion assigning to 'String' (aka 'char *') from 'int' [-Wint-conversion]
  temp = Function_prn__void(&p->Foo.member1); 
       ^ ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
./out/main.c:1714:10: warning: implicit declaration of function 'Function_prn__void' is invalid in C99 [-Wimplicit-function-declaration]
  temp = Function_prn__void(&p->Foo.member1);
         ^
./out/main.c:1714:8: warning: incompatible integer to pointer conversion assigning to 'String' (aka 'char *') from 'int' [-Wint-conversion]
  temp = Function_prn__void(&p->Foo.member1);
       ^ ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
./out/main.c:1746:10: warning: implicit declaration of function 'Function_prn__void' is invalid in C99 [-Wimplicit-function-declaration]
  temp = Function_prn__void(&p->Foo.member1); 
         ^
./out/main.c:1746:8: warning: incompatible integer to pointer conversion assigning to 'String' (aka 'char *') from 'int' [-Wint-conversion]
  temp = Function_prn__void(&p->Foo.member1); 
       ^ ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
./out/main.c:1768:10: warning: implicit declaration of function 'Function_prn__void' is invalid in C99 [-Wimplicit-function-declaration]
  temp = Function_prn__void(&p->Foo.member1);
         ^
./out/main.c:1768:8: warning: incompatible integer to pointer conversion assigning to 'String' (aka 'char *') from 'int' [-Wint-conversion]
  temp = Function_prn__void(&p->Foo.member1);
       ^ ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
./out/main.c:2932:17: error: expected ')'
void _Lambda_(EG.Foo (String.copy "Foo") (fn _LT__GT_ [] ()))_7() {
                ^
./out/main.c:2932:14: note: to match this '('
void _Lambda_(EG.Foo (String.copy "Foo") (fn _LT__GT_ [] ()))_7() {
             ^
./out/main.c:2932:62: error: expected function body after function declarator
void _Lambda_(EG.Foo (String.copy "Foo") (fn _LT__GT_ [] ()))_7() {
```

When using a def, this works fine.

```clojure
(deftype EG (Foo [String (Fn [] ())]) (Bar []))
(def quack (EG.Foo @"foo" (fn [] ())))
(type quack)
quack : EG
```

Some users (such as myself) may occasionally want to use the repl to simply evaluate an expression to check that it's valid. It might help if we can make the repl bind to a global dummy/catchall variable whenever a user enters something like `(EG.Foo @"foo" (fn [] ()))` at the top level. For example, SML implementations often use a global called `it` for this sort of thing; `it` is always bound to the last evaluated expression.

This need to `def` can also make it tricky to work with evaluating functions that use these definitions:
```clojure
(deftype EG (Foo [(Fn [] ())]) (Bar []))
(defn g [x] (match x (EG.Foo f) (f) (EG.Bar) ()))
(def q (EG.Foo (fn [] ())))
(g @&q) ;; Broken!
/out/main.c:1833:10: warning: implicit declaration of function 'Function_prn__void' is invalid in C99 [-Wimplicit-function-declaration]
  temp = Function_prn__void(&p->Foo.member1); 
         ^
./out/main.c:1833:8: warning: incompatible integer to pointer conversion assigning to 'String' (aka 'char *') from 'int' [-Wint-conversion]
  temp = Function_prn__void(&p->Foo.member1); 
;;;;; etc....

(def r (g @&q)) ;; works just fine!
(type r)
r : () ;; unit, the result we expect from computing g of q.
```

(As part of this exercise, I also had some fun with pointers.)
```clojure
(defn qux [] (IO.println "foo"))
(Pointer.to-ref (address qux))
Î»
(def x (Pointer.to-ref (address qux)))
(type x)
x : (Ref (Î» [] ()))
[x]
=> [(def x (Pointer.to-ref__Fn___void (address qux)))]
@x
Î»
(@x)
Î»
foo
(~x)
foo
```

comment.body:
Huh, I don't get the same C compiler errors as you. Both in the repl and when loading from a file I get a bunch of warnings regarding and implicit declaration of `Function_copy__void_Fn___void` plus an error:

```
/Carp/out/main.c:1635:22: error: assigning to 'Lambda' from incompatible type 'int'
    copy.Foo.member1 = Function_copy__void_Fn___void(&(pRef->Foo.member1));
```

This probably means that there is a dependency function that is not generated...

I've solved a bunch of similar bugs in Concretize/Emit before, so I'm happy to fix this unless you want to take it on?

issue.title: Non-exhaustive patterns in Concretize
issue.body:
When I attempt to use the following definitions, I get an error about non-exhaustive patterns in `concretize.hs`

```clojure
(def scheduled-propagators (the (Array (Fn [] ())) (zero)))                 
    ;; all propagators ever scheduled during the scheduler's lifetime.          
(def history (the (Array (Fn [] ())) (zero)))  

(defn run-alerted []                                                        
        (do                                                                     
          (clear-schedule)                                                      
          (foreach [propagator &scheduled-propagators]                          
            (~propagator))                                                      
          (if (propagators-scheduled?)                                          
              (run-alerted)                                                     
              (State.Done))))    
```

My guess is that concretize doesn't yet account for the `()` type? either that or there's something wrong in my carp code. 

Happy to look into this!

comment.body:
So, here was my dumb error:

`(deftype (State a) Done (Value [a]))`

The repl/compiler treats this definition as a-ok, but will choke in a variety of ways when you attempt to use the first form as: `State.Done`.

It seems as though the particular Concretize error I encountered relies on a couple of conditions...so I'm still working on reproducing precisely that issue, but it does seem as though the root cause is the above definition of the `State` sumtype being accepted. It seems as though the concretize error is encountered if you use the invalid type definition in a particular way. I have dug into reproducing it yet, but here is the function it was hung up on (when State is defined incorrectly as I defined it above)

```clojure
    (private run-alerted)                                                                                                                               
    (doc run-alerted "Run all of the alterted propagators.")                                                                                            
    (sig run-alerted (Fn [] (State a)))                                                                                                                 
    (defn run-alerted []                                                                                                                                
        (do                                                                                                                                             
          (clear-schedule)                                                                                                                              
          (foreach [propagator &scheduled-propagators]                                                                                                  
            (~propagator))                                                                                                                              
          (if (propagators-scheduled?)                                                                                                                  
              (run-alerted)                                                                                                                             
              (State.Done))))        
```

If I had to guess it probably has something to do with the fact that [a] is not bound using `the` nor is it contextualized by a function argument.

The definition of `State` above should probably emit the `Sumtype` error like this def does:

```
(deftype Foo Nada)
Invalid type definition for 'Foo':

I failed to read `Nada` as a sumtype case at line 1, column 14 in 'REPL'.

Sumtype cases look like this: `(Foo [Int typevar])`
```

commits.message: headerparse: fix for comments after decl

Merge pull request #478 from hellerve/headerparse-comment-fix

Fix headerparse for comments after decl

pull_request.title: Fix headerparse for comments after decl
pull_request.body:
This PR fixes the headerparse to accept input such as:

```c
int x(); // this comment destroys headerparse
void y();
```

Inline comments made the header parser choke before because it expected the rest of the line to consist of `stringOrTab` parsemes.

Cheers

repo.name: Carp
repo.description: A statically typed lisp, without a GC, for high performance applications

repo.name: Carp
repo.description: A statically typed lisp, without a GC, for real-time applications.

issue.title: Non-exhaustive patterns in Concretize
issue.body:
When I attempt to use the following definitions, I get an error about non-exhaustive patterns in `concretize.hs`

```clojure
(def scheduled-propagators (the (Array (Fn [] ())) (zero)))                 
    ;; all propagators ever scheduled during the scheduler's lifetime.          
(def history (the (Array (Fn [] ())) (zero)))  

(defn run-alerted []                                                        
        (do                                                                     
          (clear-schedule)                                                      
          (foreach [propagator &scheduled-propagators]                          
            (~propagator))                                                      
          (if (propagators-scheduled?)                                          
              (run-alerted)                                                     
              (State.Done))))    
```

My guess is that concretize doesn't yet account for the `()` type? either that or there's something wrong in my carp code. 

Happy to look into this!

comment.body: Hm, thatâ€™s a hint that thereâ€™s probably just some logical error in my code thatâ€™s the root of this instance. Nonetheless, we should probably fix the non-exhaustive pattern and throw a meaningful error if we can. Iâ€™ll try to tease out the error and provide a small reproducible sample.

pull_request.title: Remove issuified todos from Todo.org
pull_request.body:
With the creation of #465 to #476, a bunch of issues found a new home and are moving out of the org file. This PR reflect that.

Cheers

repo.name: Carp
repo.description: A statically typed lisp, without a GC, for real-time applications.

issue.title: Make error reporting in Eval better
issue.body:
The error reporting in `Eval` could be better. Itâ€™s not always possible to construct an error, especially one with the correct source location; it definitely should be!

Cheers

issue.title: Better constraint weight
issue.body:
The weights for constraints are not an exact science, but still contribute to the error reporting experience. Experimenting with them to get more helpful errors would probably be a good idea.

Cheers

issue.title: Macro errors should show both the calling code and the macro
issue.body:
Debugging macros in Carp is actually quite a nice experience, except that the source location often only shows half of the truth.

In an ideal world, weâ€™d have access to both the caller and the macro in the error message and show the error location for both of them!

Cheers

issue.title: Unify long and short error messages
issue.body:
Long error messages are for calling the compiler from the command line, while short error messages are for integrating into editors mostly. Sadly, not all of the error messages are equally helpful or thought out, or even have both forms. This needs to be fixed for a better development experience.

Cheers
